column17: 'Osamu Dazai’s immortal—and supposedly autobiographical—work of Japanese literature
column18: is perfectly adapted here into a manga by Junji Ito. The imagery wrenches open the text of the novel one line at a time to sublimate Yozo’s mental landscape into something even more delicate and grotesque. This is the ultimate in art by Ito
column19: proof that nothing can surpass the terror of the human psyche.'
column20: 'Junji Ito'
column21: 'Japan'

column17: 'Commissioned in 1975 by Thomas Nelson
column18: 130 international and multi-denominational Bible scholars
column19: church leaders
column20: and lay Christians worked for seven years to create a completely new
column21: modern translation of Scripture that retained the purity and stylistic beauty of the King James Version'

column17: 'Seventeenth-century Japan: Two Portuguese Jesuit priests travel to a country hostile to their religion
column18: where feudal lords force the faithful to publicly renounce their beliefs. Eventually captured and forced to watch their Japanese Christian brothers lay down their lives for their faith
column19: the priests bear witness to unimaginable cruelties that test their own beliefs.'
column20: 'Shusaku Endo'
column21: 'Japan'

column17: 'Beginning with The Call of the Cthulhu
column18: the first story of the Cthulhu Mythos
column19: and demonstrating the highly original combination of the supernatural
column20: horror and science fiction that was to influence generations of fantasy writers
column21: this collection of 20 short stories by HP Lovecraft (1890-1937) presents his best-known tales
column23: The Rats in the Walls and the novella set in the wastes of Antarctica

column17: 'With unflinching gaze and uncompromising intensity Julius Evola analyzes the spiritual and cultural malaise at the heart of Western civilization and all that passes for progress in the modern world. As a gadfly
column18: Evola spares no one and nothing in his survey of what we have lost and where we are headed.'
column19: 'Julius Evola'
column20: 'Italy'
column21: 'Philosophy'

column17: 'Presented in the form of a dialogue between Socrates and three different interlocutors
column18: it is an inquiry into the notion of a perfect community and the ideal individual within it. During the conversation other questions are raised: what is goodness; what is reality; what is knowledge? The Republic also addresses the purpose of education and the role of both women and men as \"guardians\" of the people.'
column19: 'Plato'
column20: 'Greece'
column21: 'Philosophy'

column17: 'Written in Greek by an intellectual Roman emperor without any intention of publication

column19: 'Marcus Aurelius'
column20: 'Italy'
column21: 'Philosophy'

column14: 'Dante’s masterpiece of literature is well matched by the peerless art of Gustave Doré. Dante and his guides

column17: with the subtle engraving of Doré’s illustrations perfectly complementing the movement from darkness through to light.'
column18: 'Dante Alighieri'
column19: 'Italy'

column16: time-tested advice has carried countless people up the ladder of success in their business and personal lives.'
column17: 'Dale Carnegie'

column14: 'The Brothers Karamasov is a murder mystery
column16: and an exploration of erotic rivalry in a series of triangular love affairs involving the “wicked and sentimental” Fyodor Pavlovich Karamazov and his three sons―the impulsive and sensual Dmitri; the coldly rational Ivan; and the healthy
column17: red-cheeked young novice Alyosha.'
column18: 'Fyodor Dostoyevsky'
column19: 'Russia'

column17: 'his classic
column18: definitive account of totalitarianism traces the emergence of modern racism as an \"ideological weapon for imperialism\"
column19: beginning with the rise of anti-Semitism in Europe in the 19th century and continuing through the New Imperialism period from 1884 to World War I.'
column20: 'Hannah Arendt'
column21: 'Germany'

column18: originally intending merely to report on the Spanish Civil War as a journalist
column19: George Orwell found himself embroiled as a participant—as a member of the Workers’ Party of Marxist Unity. Fighting against the Fascists
column20: he described in painfully vivid and occasionally comic detail life in the trenches—with a “democratic army” composed of men with no ranks
column21: no titles
column22: and often no weapons—and his near fatal wounding. As the politics became tangled
column23: Orwell was pulled into a heartbreaking conflict between his own personal ideals and the complicated realities of political power struggles.'

column18: London is a grim city in the totalitarian state of Oceania where Big Brother is always watching you and the Thought Police can practically read your mind. Winston Smith is a man in grave danger for the simple reason that his memory still functions. Drawn into a forbidden love affair
column19: Winston finds the courage to join a secret revolutionary organization called the Brotherhood
column20: dedicated to the destruction of the Party. Together with his beloved Julia
column21: he hazards his life in a deadly match against the powers that be.'

column17: 'Among the most profound and influential explorations of mind-expanding psychedelic drugs ever written
column18: here are two complete classic books—The Doors of Perception and Heaven and Hell—in which Aldous Huxley
column19: author of Brave New World
column20: reveals the mind\'s remote frontiers and the unmapped areas of human consciousness. This edition also features an additional essay
column21: \"Drugs That Shape Men\'s Minds
column22: \" now included for the first time.'

column16: 'Sebestyen reveals Lenin as a ruthless and single-minded despot and a \"product of his time and place: a violent
column17: tyrannical and corrupt Russia\". He seized power in a coup
column18: promised a revolution
column19: a socialist utopia for the people
column20: offered simple solutions to complex issues
column21: and constantly lied; in fact what he created was more \"a mirror image of the Romanov autocracy\". He authorized the deaths of thousands of people and created a system based on the idea that political terror against opponents was justified for the greater ideal. One of his old comrades who had once admired him said he \"desired the good...but created evil\". And that would include his invention of Stalin
column22: who would take Lenin\'s system of the gulag and the secret police to new heights.'

column17: 'In his most famous and controversial book
column18: Utopia
column19: Thomas More imagines a perfect island nation where thousands live in peace and harmony
column20: men and women are both educated
column21: and all property is communal. Through dialogue and correspondence between the protagonist Raphael Hythloday and his friends and contemporaries
column22: More explores the theories behind war
column25: and wealth distribution and imagines the day-to-day lives of those citizens enjoying freedom from fear

column17: 'For several years of his turbulent life
column18: Seneca was the guiding hand of the Roman Empire. His inspired reasoning derived mainly from the Stoic principles
column19: which had originally been developed some centuries earlier in Athens. This selection of Seneca\'s letters shows him upholding the austere ethical ideals of Stoicism—the wisdom of the self-possessed person immune to overmastering emotions and life’s setbacks—while valuing friendship and the courage of ordinary men
column20: and criticizing the harsh treatment  of slaves and the cruelties in the gladiatorial arena. The humanity and wit revealed in Seneca’s interpretation of Stoicism is a moving and inspiring declaration of the dignity of the individual mind.'
column21: 'Seneca'

column17: 'Aldous Huxley\'s profoundly important classic of world literature
column18: Brave New World is a searching vision of an unequal
column19: technologically-advanced future where humans are genetically bred
column20: socially indoctrinated
column21: and pharmaceutically anesthetized to passively uphold an authoritarian ruling order–all at the cost of our freedom

column17: 'After his great portrayal of a guilty man in Crime and Punishment
column18: Dostoevsky set out in The Idiot to portray a man of pure innocence. The twenty-six-year-old Prince Myshkin
column19: following a stay of several years in a Swiss sanatorium
column20: returns to Russia to collect an inheritance and “be among people.” Even before he reaches home he meets the dark Rogozhin
column21: a rich merchant’s son whose obsession with the beautiful Nastasya Filippovna eventually draws all three of them into a tragic denouement. In Petersburg the prince finds himself a stranger in a society obsessed with money
column23: and manipulation. Scandal escalates to murder as Dostoevsky traces the surprising effect of this “positively beautiful man” on the people around him
column24: leading to a final scene that is one of the most powerful in all of world literature.'

column17: 'One of the most remarkable characters in literature
column18: the unnamed narrator of Dostoevsky\'s most revolutionary novel is a former official who has defiantly withdrawn into an underground existence. In full retreat from society
column19: he scrawls a passionate
column20: obsessive
column21: self-contradictory narrative that serves as a devastating attack on social utopianism and an assertion of man’s essentially irrational nature.'

column17: 'When Raskolnikov
column18: an impoverished student living in the St. Petersburg of the tsars
column19: commits an act of murder and theft
column20: he sets into motion a story that is almost unequalled in world literature for its excruciating suspense
column21: its atmospheric vividness
column22: and its depth of characterization and vision. Dostoevsky’s drama of sin
column24: and redemption transforms the sordid story of an old woman’s murder into the nineteenth century’s profoundest and most compelling philosophical novel.'

column17: 'The Gulag Archipelago is an exhaustive and compelling account based on Solzhenitsyn’s own eight years in Soviet prison camps
column18: on other prisoners’ stories committed to his photographic memory while in detention
column19: and on letters and historical sources. The work represents the author’s attempt to compile a literary and historical record of the Soviet regime’s comprehensive but deeply irrational use of terror against its own population. A testimonial to Stalinist atrocities
column20: The Gulag Archipelago devastated readers outside the Soviet Union with its descriptions of the brutality of the Soviet regime.'
column21: 'Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn'

column17: 'This beloved novel tells the story of Edmond Dantès
column18: wrongfully imprisoned for life in the supposedly impregnable sea fortress
column19: the Château d’If. After a daring escape
column20: and after unearthing a hidden treasure revealed to him by a fellow prisoner
column21: he devotes the rest of his life to tracking down and punishing the enemies who wronged him.'

column17: 3rd Edition'
column18: 'Python Crash Course is the world’s best-selling guide to the Python programming language. This fast-paced
column19: thorough introduction will have you writing programs
column20: solving problems
column21: and developing functioning applications in no time.'

column17: 'Alif Baa is the first volume of the best-selling Al-Kitaab Arabic Language Program
column18: now in its third edition. In this edition of Alif Baa: Introduction to Arabic Letters and Sounds with Website
column19: English-speaking students will use the integrated method of learning colloquial and formal (spoken and written) Arabic together. Alif Baa provides learners with all the material necessary to learn the sounds of Arabic
column20: write its letters
column21: and begin speaking Arabic.The accompanying companion website―included with the book―offers fully integrated exercises to use alongside the text.'

column17: 'Paradise Lost is an epic poem in blank verse by the 17th-century English poet John Milton (1608–1674). It is considered to be Milton\'s major work
column18: and it helped solidify his reputation as one of the greatest English poets of his time. The poem concerns the biblical story of the Fall of Man: the temptation of Adam and Eve by the fallen angel Satan and their expulsion from the Garden of Eden. Milton\'s purpose
column19: as stated in Book I
column20: is to \"justify the ways of God to men.\"'
column21: 'John Milton'

column17: 'Why do we remember the past and not the future? What does it mean for time to \"flow\"? Do we exist in time or does time exist in us? In lyric
column18: accessible prose
column19: Carlo Rovelli invites us to consider questions about the nature of time that continue to puzzle physicists and philosophers alike.\n\nFor most readers this is unfamiliar terrain. We all experience time
column20: but the more scientists learn about it
column21: the more mysterious it remains. We think of it as uniform and universal
column22: moving steadily from past to future
column23: measured by clocks. Rovelli tears down these assumptions one by one
column24: revealing a strange universe where at the most fundamental level time disappears. He explains how the theory of quantum gravity attempts to understand and give meaning to the resulting extreme landscape of this timeless world.'

column17: 'Named one of Time\'s 100 Best Books
column18: Ubik is a mind-bending
column19: classic novel about the perception of reality from Philip K. Dick
column20: the Hugo Award-winning author of The Man in the High Castle. “From the stuff of space opera
column21: Dick spins a deeply unsettling existential horror story
column22: a nightmare you’ll never be sure you’ve woken up from.”—Lev Grossman
column23: Time Glen Runciter runs a lucrative business — deploying his teams of anti-psychics to corporate clients who want privacy and security from psychic spies. But when he and his top team are ambushed by a rival
column24: he is gravely injured and placed in “half-life
column25: ” a dreamlike state of suspended animation. Soon
column27: the surviving members of the team begin experiencing some strange phenomena
column28: such as Runciter’s face appearing on coins and the world seeming to move backward in time.'

column17: 'A treasure worth killing for. Sam Spade
column18: a slightly shopworn private eye with his own solitary code of ethics. A perfumed grafter named Joel Cairo
column19: a fat man name Gutman
column20: and Brigid O’Shaughnessy
column21: a beautiful and treacherous woman whose loyalties shift at the drop of a dime. These are the ingredients of Dashiell Hammett\'s iconic

column16: 'Food of the Gods: The Search for the Original Tree of Knowledge'
column17: 'Why
column18: as a species
column19: are humans so fascinated by altered states of consciousness? Can altered states reveal something to us about our origins and our place in nature? In Food of the Gods
column20: ethnobotanist Terence McKenna’s research on man’s ancient relationship with chemicals opens a doorway to the divine
column21: and perhaps a solution for saving our troubled world. McKenna provides a revisionist look at the historical role of drugs in the East and the West
column27: and even television—illustrating the human desire for the “food of the gods” and the powerful potential to replace abuse of illegal drugs with a shamanic understanding

column17: 'Combat
column18: the most intense and dynamic environment imaginable
column19: teaches the toughest leadership lessons
column20: with absolutely everything at stake. Jocko Willink and Leif Babin learned this reality first-hand on the most violent and dangerous battlefield in Iraq. As leaders of SEAL Team Three’s Task Unit Bruiser
column21: their mission was one many thought impossible: help U.S. forces secure Ramadi
column23: insurgent-held city deemed “all but lost.” In gripping
column27: they learned that leadership―at every level―is the most important factor in whether a team succeeds or fails.'

column16: 'Arabic Stories for Language Learners: Traditional Middle Eastern Tales In Arabic and English'
column17: 'The traditional stories of a country are invaluable at providing insight into understanding the culture
column18: history and language of a people. A great way to learn Arabic
column19: the sixty-six stories found in Arabic Stories for Language Learners present the vocabulary and grammar used every day in Arabic-speaking countries. Pulled from a wide variety of sources that have been edited and simplified for learning purposes
column20: these stories are presented in parallel Arabic and English
column21: facilitating language learning in the classroom and via self-study. Each story is followed by a series of questions in Arabic and English to test comprehension and encourage discussion.'

column17: 'Beyond Good and Evil: Prelude to a Philosophy of the Future is a book by philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche
column18: first published in 1886. It draws on and expands the ideas of his previous work
column19: Thus Spoke Zarathustra
column20: but with a more critical and polemical approach. In Beyond Good and Evil
column21: Nietzsche accuses past philosophers of lacking critical sense and blindly accepting dogmatic premises in their consideration of morality. Specifically
column22: he accuses them of founding grand metaphysical systems upon the faith that the good man is the opposite of the evil man
column23: rather than just a different expression of the same basic impulses that find more direct expression in the evil man. The work moves into the realm \"beyond good and evil\" in the sense of leaving behind the traditional morality which Nietzsche subjects to a destructive critique in favour of what he regards as an affirmative approach that fearlessly confronts the perspectival nature of knowledge and the perilous condition of the modern individual.'

column16: 'The Lucifer Effect: Understanding How Good People Turn Evil'
column17: 'Renowned social psychologist and creator of the Stanford Prison Experiment Philip Zimbardo explores the mechanisms that make good people do bad things
column18: how moral people can be seduced into acting immorally
column19: and what this says about the line separating good from evil.\n\nThe Lucifer Effect explains how—and the myriad reasons why—we are all susceptible to the lure of “the dark side.” Drawing on examples from history as well as his own trailblazing research
column20: Zimbardo details how situational forces and group dynamics can work in concert to make monsters out of decent men and women. '
column21: 'Philip Zimbardo'

column17: 'A girl named Rose is riding her new bike near her home in Deadwood
column18: South Dakota
column19: when she falls through the earth. She wakes up at the bottom of a square hole
column20: its walls glowing with intricate carvings. But the firemen who come to save her peer down upon something even stranger: a little girl in the palm of a giant metal hand.\n\nSeventeen years later
column21: the mystery of the bizarre artifact remains unsolved—its origins
column23: and purpose unknown. Its carbon dating defies belief; military reports are redacted; theories are floated
column24: then rejected.\n\nBut some can never stop searching for answers.'

column16: 'Boyd: The Fighter Pilot Who Changed the Art of War'
column17: 'John Boyd may be the most remarkable unsung hero in all of American military history. Some remember him as the greatest U.S. fighter pilot ever -- the man who
column18: in simulated air-to-air combat
column19: defeated every challenger in less than forty seconds. Some recall him as the father of our country\'s most legendary fighter aircraft -- the F-15 and F-16. Still others think of Boyd as the most influential military theorist since Sun Tzu. They know only half the story.'
column20: 'Robert Coram'
column21: 'United States'

column17: 'From examining the role evolving humans have played in the global ecosystem to charting the rise of empires
column18: Sapiens integrates history and science to reconsider accepted narratives
column19: connect past developments with contemporary concerns
column20: and examine specific events within the context of larger ideas. Dr. Harari also compels us to look ahead
column21: because over the last few decades humans have begun to bend laws of natural selection that have governed life for the past four billion years. We are acquiring the ability to design not only the world around us
column22: but also ourselves. Where is this leading us
column23: and what do we want to become?'

column17: 'When Admiral Richard E. Byrd set out on his second Antarctic expedition in 1934
column18: he was already an international hero for having piloted the first flights over the North and South Poles. His plan for this latest adventure was to spend six months alone near the bottom of the world
column19: gathering weather data and indulging his desire “to taste peace and quiet long enough to know how good they really are.” But early on things went terribly wrong. Isolated in the pervasive polar night with no hope of release until spring
column20: Byrd began suffering inexplicable symptoms of mental and physical illness. By the time he discovered that carbon monoxide from a defective stovepipe was poisoning him
column21: Byrd was already engaged in a monumental struggle to save his life and preserve his sanity.'

column17: 'The Prince is a 16th-century political treatise written by Italian diplomat and political theorist Niccolò Machiavelli as an instruction guide for new princes and royals. The general theme of The Prince is of accepting that the aims of princes – such as glory and survival – can justify the use of immoral means to achieve those ends.'
column18: 'Niccolo Machiavelli'
column19: 'Italy'
column20: 'Politics'

column16: 'Bullets and Opium: Real-Life Stories of China After the Tiananmen Square Massacre'
column17: 'Much has been written about the Tiananmen Square protests
column18: but very little exists in the words of those who were actually there.\n\nFor over seven years
column19: Liao Yiwu—a master of contemporary Chinese literature
column20: imprisoned and persecuted as a counter-revolutionary until he fled the country in 2011—secretly interviewed survivors of the devastating 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre. Tortured
column21: imprisoned
column22: and forced into silence and the margins of Chinese society for thirty years
column23: their harrowing and unforgettable stories are now finally revealed in this “indispensable historical document” (Kirkus Reviews

column17: 'Dating to the ninth century B.C.
column18: Homer’s timeless poem still vividly conveys the horror and heroism of men and gods wrestling with towering emotions and battling amidst devastation and destruction
column19: as it moves inexorably to the wrenching
column20: tragic conclusion of the Trojan War. Renowned classicist Bernard Knox observes in his superb introduction that although the violence of the Iliad is grim and relentless
column21: it coexists with both images of civilized life and a poignant yearning for peace.'

column17: 'Translated with the close support of leading contemporary masters and hailed as “a tremendous accomplishment
column18: ” this book faithfully presents the insights and intentions of the original work. It includes one of the most detailed and compelling descriptions of the after-death state in world literature
column19: practices that can transform our experience of daily life
column20: guidance on helping those who are dying
column21: and an inspirational perspective on coping with bereavement.'

column17: 'Das Kapital is a revolutionary book; forged during the political and industrial revolutions of the nineteenth century
column18: it became the keystone of many Communist revolutions of the twentieth century. In this comprehensive analysis of capitalist economics and articulation of his theory of class conflict
column19: Karl Marx (1818-1883) relentlessly argues that the accumulation of capital can only be achieved by bourgeoisie exploitation of the working classes. Das Kapital has not only changed history
column20: but also human thought
column21: becoming a foundational text in materialist philosophy

column16: 'The Archaeology of Knowledge: And the Discourse on Language'
column17: 'The Archaeology of Knowledge begins at the level of \"things aid\" and moves quickly to illuminate the connections between knowledge
column18: language
column19: and action in a style at once profound and personal. A summing up of Foucault\'s own methodological assumptions
column20: this book is also a first step toward a genealogy of the way we live now.'
column21: 'Michel Foucault'

column18: Jean-Paul Sartre published his masterpiece
column19: Being and Nothingness
column20: and laid the foundation of his legacy as one of the greatest twentieth century philosophers. A brilliant and radical account of the human condition
column21: Being and Nothingness explores what gives our lives significance.\n\nIn a new and more accessible translation
column22: this foundational text argues that we alone create our values and our existence is characterized by freedom and the inescapability of choice. Far from being an internal
column23: passive container for our thoughts and experiences
column24: human consciousness is constantly projecting itself into the outside world and imbuing it with meaning.'

column17: 'Metamorphosis is a novella written by Franz Kafka which was first published in 1915. One of Kafka\'s best-known works
column18: The Metamorphosis tells the story of salesman Gregor Samsa who wakes one morning to find himself inexplicably transformed into a huge insect
column19: subsequently struggling to adjust to this new condition. The novella has been widely discussed among literary critics
column20: with differing interpretations being offered.'
column21: 'Franz Kafka'

column17: 'Behind the subterfuge
column18: Camus explores what he termed \"the nakedness of man faced with the absurd\" and describes the condition of reckless alienation and spiritual exhaustion that characterized so much of twentieth-century life. \n\n“The Stranger is a strikingly modern text and Matthew Ward’s translation will enable readers to appreciate why Camus’s stoical anti-hero and ­devious narrator remains one of the key expressions of a postwar Western malaise
column19: and one of the cleverest exponents of a literature of ambiguity.” –from the Introduction by Peter Dunwoodie'
column20: 'Albert Camus'
column21: 'French'

column17: 'Written in 1914
column18: The Trial is the terrifying tale of Josef K.
column19: a respectable bank officer who is suddenly and inexplicably arrested and must defend himself against a charge about which he can get no information. Whether read as an existential tale
column20: a parable
column21: or a prophecy of the excesses of modern bureaucracy wedded to the madness of totalitarianism
column22: Kafka\'s nightmare has resonated with chilling truth for generations of readers. This new edition is based upon the work of an international team of experts who have restored the text
column24: and their division to create a version that is as close as possible to the way the author left it.'

column17: 'First published in 1961
column18: and reissued in this sixtieth anniversary edition with a powerful new introduction by Cornel West
column19: Frantz Fanon’s The Wretched of the Earth is a masterfuland timeless interrogation of race
column20: colonialism
column21: psychological trauma
column23: and a continuing influence on movements from Black Lives Matter to decolonization. A landmark text for revolutionaries and activists
column24: The Wretched of the Earth is an eternal touchstone for civil rights
column27: and Black consciousness movements around the world. Alongside Cornel West’s introduction
column28: the book features critical essays by Jean-Paul Sartre and Homi K. Bhabha. This sixtieth anniversary edition of Fanon’s most famous text stands proudly alongside such pillars of anti-colonialism and anti-racism as Edward Said’s Orientalism and The Autobiography of Malcolm X.'

column16: 'Mine Were of Trouble: A Nationalist Account of the Spanish Civil War'
column17: 'Spain
column18: 1936. Escalating violence between left- and right-wing political factions boils over. Military officers stage a coup against a democratically elected
column19: Soviet-backed
column20: government. The country is thrown into chaos as centuries-old tensions return to the forefront. Hundreds of thousands of Spaniards choose sides and engage in the most devastating combat since the First World War. For loyalists to the Republic
column21: the fight is seen as one for equality and their idea of progress. For the rebels
column22: the struggle is a preemptive strike by tradition against an attempted communist takeover.\n\nThousands of foreigners
column24: join the struggle. Most fight with the Soviet-sponsored International Brigades or other militias aligned with the loyalist “Republicans”. Only a few side with the rebel “Nationalists”. One of these rare volunteers for the Nationalists was Peter Kemp
column25: a young British law student. Kemp
column26: despite having little training or command of the Spanish language
column27: was moved by the Nationalist struggle against international Communism. Using forged documents
column28: he sneaked into Spain and joined a traditionalist militia
column30: with which he saw intense fighting. Later
column31: he volunteered to join the legendary and ruthless Spanish Foreign Legion
column32: where he distinguished himself with heroism. Because of this bravery
column33: he was one of the few foreign volunteers granted a private audience with Generalissimo Francisco Franco.'
